title: 114_s3544
content: The Act is titled the "Wildland Firefighter Retirement and Disability Compensation Benefits Act of 2016". It includes provisions for civil service retention rights. Section 8151 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define a 'covered employee' as a wildland firefighter who sustained an injury on duty preventing them from performing firefighter duties. A covered employee, as defined in section 8151 of title 5, United States Code, is entitled to receive the same retirement benefits as they would have received if not injured or disabled, without requiring additional years of service. The term 'firefighter' is defined in section 8331. Under regulations issued by the Office of Personnel Management, the last employer must offer the employee the right to resume their former position or an equivalent one if the injury or disability is overcome within 1 year of compensation commencement. This also applies if the compensable disability recurs after the employee resumes full-time employment with the United States. The last employer must offer the employee the right to resume their former position or an equivalent one if the injury or disability is overcome within 1 year of compensation commencement. Additionally, efforts should be made to place the employee in the former or equivalent position within the department or agency. The Wildland Firefighter Retirement and Disability Compensation Benefits Act of 2016 requires covered employees to make a payment equal to the deducted amount if they want to receive retirement benefits after being injured or disabled. SEC. 3. COMPUTATION OF PAY. Section 8114 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define 'covered overtime pay' for wildland firefighters and include it as part of pay calculations. The amendment made by subsection (a) regarding differential in cost of living or special circumstances for pay, bonus or premium pay for extraordinary service, and hazardous service in time of war, will take effect on October 1, 2016.
